awd_titl_txt: Early Dynamical Instabilities in Extrasolar Planetary Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
A team from the California Institute of Technology will build a full picture for the formation and early evolution of the most commonly occurring planets found around nearby stars. Over the past two decades, surveys have shown that planet formation is efficient across the Galaxy. The most common mode of planet formation appears to generate planets a few times larger than Earth, with orbital periods smaller than one year. Scientists have further shown that systems of planets outside our Solar System exhibit a uniform pattern in their orbits and masses. The project will build a model for the formation and early evolution of these planets. The program will involve public engagement, training of graduate students, and collaborations with teachers and students from local high schools.

The proposed research program will quantify the dynamical instability-driven early evolution of Super-Earths, with an eye towards identifying scattering mechanisms, modeling physical consequences, and compiling the associated observational predictions. First and foremost, the execution of this work will answer the fundamental question of how orbital instabilities among sub-Jovian planets are activated in the proportion needed to explain their period ratio distribution. Second, the investigators will determine whether or not instability-driven sculpting can satisfy existing observational constraints. The investigators will determine how tidal dissipation and interactions of planets with leftover debris shape the current architectures of sub-Jovian extrasolar planetary systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research, supported by the NSF grant titled "Early Dynamical Instabilities in Extrasolar Planetary Systems," has made significant strides in understanding the formation and evolution of planetary systems beyond our own. This project focused on the early dynamical instabilities that occur as planets form and migrate within their stellar systems, shedding light on some of the most fundamental questions about our universe.

Intellectual Merit

Over the course of this project, we developed several theoretical models and conducted numerous simulations to understand how sub-Jovian exoplanets, such as super-Earths and mini-Neptunes, form and evolve. One of our key findings was the development of a self-consistent model for dust-gas coupling in protoplanetary disks, which provided insights into the growth of planetesimals—the building blocks of planets. Our subsequent research demonstrated how these planets grow through collisions among rocky bodies until they reach a size regulated by their isolation and migration within the disk.

We also explored the detailed migratory behavior of these planets, discovering that they tend to stabilize at the inner edge of their protoplanetary disks, before relaxing through dynamical instabilities. Among other things, this finding helps explain why many exoplanets are found orbiting their stars with similar periods. Furthermore, our work on resonance capture revealed how migrating planets can become locked in orbital resonances, leading to the orderly arrangement of planetary systems observed today.

Shifting the focus back to our own solar system, we applied our theoretical models to the Titan-Hyperion resonance in the Saturnian system, and offered a new explanation for the long-term evolution of these moons. This work suggests that Hyperion’s irregular tumbling increases tidal dissipation dramatically, which balances resonant excitation from Titan's migration, maintaining Hyperion’s eccentricity in a stable configuration over the lifetime of the solar system.

Broader Impacts

Beyond the scientific advancements, this project has had substantial broader impacts, particularly in education and public outreach. We engaged high school students and educators through Caltech's summer research connection program, providing them with hands-on research experiences that inspired interest in planetary science and STEM fields. These outreach efforts have helped foster a new generation of scientists and engineers, promoting scientific literacy and critical thinking skills in the broader community.

The project's findings have been disseminated through numerous peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations, ensuring that the scientific community and the public are informed about our advancements. Our work contributes to a deeper understanding of how planets form and evolve, which is essential for the ongoing search for habitable worlds beyond our solar system. By enhancing our knowledge of planetary systems, this research supports the broader quest to understand the origins of Earth and the potential for life elsewhere in the universe.

In summary, this project has significantly advanced our understanding of early planetary system dynamics, provided valuable educational opportunities, and contributed to the broader public appreciation of planetary science. Our findings offer a robust framework for future research and continue to inspire curiosity about the cosmos.
